title: Mo Awards
text:
The Mo Awards, technically The Australian Entertainment Mo Awards, a now defunct award system, were an annual Australian entertainment industry award, that where established in 1975, to recognise achievements in live entertainment in Australia.
The Mo Awards began as a state only honour in <a href="New%20South%20Wales">New South Wales</a> known as the Star Awards when local entertainers started the awards to promote live entertainment in New South Wales. When singer <a href="Johnny%20O%27Keefe">Johnny O'Keefe</a> became chairman in 1976, he decided the awards should become an Australia-wide national awards program. Entertainer <a href="Don%20Lane">Don Lane</a> then proposed the awards be renamed the Mo Awards in honour of Australian comedian and vaudevillian <a href="Roy%20Rene">Roy Rene</a>, who used the <a href="stage%20name">stage name</a> "Mo McCackie." 
The award statue was designed by H. K. Fischer, model maker of <a href="Morisset%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Morisset</a>.
The award categories where reviewed annually and adapted to new trends in the Australian entertainment sector; categories included awards in: <a href="musical%20theatre">musical theatre</a>, <a href="opera">opera</a>, <a href="Classical%20music">Classical music</a>, <a href="dance">dance</a>, <a href="comedy">comedy</a>, <a href="rock%20music">rock music</a>, <a href="jazz">jazz</a>, <a href="country%20music">country music</a>, <a href="Play%20%28theatre%29">plays</a> and <a href="variety%20show">variety show</a>s.
The violinist <a href="Martin%20Lass">Martin Lass</a> won the Mo Award for Instrumental Excellence for seven years running from 1984 until 1990.
